Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: On-chip Multi-Channel Millimeter-wave Wireless Links for Multi-core Platforms

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT: With the well-known trend of continued CMOS scaling, as per Moore?s Law, traditional on-chip interconnect systems are projected to soon reach the point of having a very limited ability to meet the performance needs and specifications of emerging many-core processors. According to the International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors (ITRS), for the longer term, material innovation with traditional scaling will no longer satisfy performance requirements and new interconnect paradigms will be needed. The computing capabilities of many-core systems can be harnessed only if the underlying on-chip communication links can perform at an acceptable level of power performance efficiency. To address this problem, design of high-bandwidth, long-range and multi-channel millimeter (mm)-wave on-chip wireless links as communication backbones targeted for many-core chips is proposed. The research goals of this proposal will be achieved by: (1) Designing on-chip, highly efficient, single and multiband miniaturized antennas for high throughput on-chip data transfer; fabrication, testing and evaluation of prototype antennas including on-chip inkjet-printed antennas and (2) Designing mm-wave transceivers that enable multiple non-overlapping, low power, broadband wireless links and performance evaluation of small-world wireless Network-on-Chip (WiNoC) architectures.
BROADER IMPACTS: This proposal addresses the design of on-chip mm-wave wireless communication links to support power efficient design of massive multi-core chips. Multi-core processing platforms have emerged to meet the performance needs of many important applications such as graphics, financial and scientific modeling, biomonitoring, networking, multimedia and wireless infrastructure. These diverse applications will benefit from the low latency, low power on-chip communication infrastructure proposed in this work. The proposed research will enhance the education of undergraduate and graduate students by allowing them to apply classroom knowledge to research problems. As part of its Tera-scale Computing Research Program, Intel is actively pursuing several projects on scalable multi-core architectures. Consequently, the proposed work aligns with an important thrust area within Intel. Students from various underrepresented groups, including women, African Americans and Hispanics will be engaged in this project. The project?s positive educational impacts will be complemented by the positive effect that the research outcomes are expected to have on society as a whole. Outcomes of the research will be broadly disseminated. In addition to publication in peer-reviewed journals, results will be presented at internationally recognized conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The efforts of this work were focused on the development of wireless links for multi-core platforms, a technology that has the potential to replace the standard hard-wire links in computing platforms. The proposed technology has offers improvements in the areas of device miniaturization, reduced signal loss, and as a result increased throughput for data channels. This is made possible through the use of millimeter-wave (mm-wave) wireless technology, operating at wireless frequencies 10-100x that of standard WiFi/GSM communications, which allows for larger channel bandwidth and miniaturized systems with the caveat of requiring intricately designed antenna structures. The development of these wireless network-on-chip (WiNoC) systems require attention to both the wireless tranceiver and the highly-integrated antennas.

The outcomes of this work can be summarized with the following: on-chip antenna design, wireless link characterization for WiNoC systems, and integration with inkjet printing technology. Wideband, highly-efficient antennas were designed and simulated in an on-chip CMOS environment for wireless channels at 60, 175, and 200 GHz. The physical properties (thickness, bulk resistivity, on/off-chip grounding) of the silicon substrate for these antennas were investigated in order to understand and minimize the dramatic effects of surface waves present in these mm-wave and sub-THz wireless regimes. The through-channel wireless links of these on-chip antennas was investigated through full-wave simulations in order to characterize the efficiency of on-chip wireless channels at different distances. This data was then coupled with that of wireless transceivers in order to outline the expectations of a practical WiNoC system's operation.

Finally, the additive manufacturing techniques of inkjet printing were investigated for integration with mm-wave WiNoC systems. These efforts included the characterization of dielectric ink formulation and processing in order to realize uniform printed dielectric films exceeding 100 μm in thickness for integration with multilayer electronic fabrication. Fully-printed multilayer antennas were demonstrated at 24.5 and 30 GHz for integration with mm-wave systems through on-chip and on-package design schemes. 

The immediate impact of this work highlights the progress of WiNoC systems for high-throughput computing and communication, however many broader implications are present. This research effort will potentially have a very significant impact in the areas of bioengineering and biomonitoring through the enabling of wireless system-on-package lab-on-a-chip topologies as well as through the efficient integration of ICs, antennas, wireless sensors, and other passive components. Furthermore, the outcomes of this effort could have a significant impact in encouraging the proliferation of the first real-world topologies of Internet-of-Things and Machine-to-Machine interaction, creating a new interactive environment for human-machine relations through the ubiquitous implementation of wireless sensing, harvesting, bio-monitoring, and telecommunication devices.
